rack.definition: a framework, typically with rails, bars, hooks, or pegs, on which items can be displayed, stored, or hung
example_sentences: I hung my coat on the rack by the door.
The store had a rack of gardening tools for sale.
She displayed her collection of hats on a rack in her bedroom.
The bike rack was full, so I had to find another place to park my bicycle.
The kitchen rack was overflowing with pots and pans.

nerve racking.definition: causing a person to feel very tense, anxious, and stressed
example_sentences: The job interview was nerve-racking, but she managed to remain composed.
Waiting for the exam results is always nerve-racking.
His constant procrastination is nerve-racking for his colleagues.
The suspenseful movie was so nerve-racking that I couldn't sit still.
Driving in heavy traffic can be nerve-racking for some people.

exhilarating.definition: causing strong feelings of excitement and happiness
example_sentences: The roller coaster ride was exhilarating, with loops and twists that sent a thrill through her.
Taking a refreshing swim in the cool ocean on a hot summer day can be quite exhilarating.
Winning the championship game was an exhilarating moment for the team and their fans.
Skydiving for the first time is an exhilarating experience that many people find both terrifying and exhilarating.
The breathtaking view from the mountain peak was truly exhilarating, making the long hike worth every step.

venturing.definition: the act or an instance of stepping out or going beyond; foraging, exploration
example_sentences: They were venturing into uncharted territory in search of the lost city.
As a group, we enjoyed venturing through the dense forest to discover hidden waterfalls.
The young entrepreneur was excited about venturing into a new business opportunity.
Venturing outside of her comfort zone, she decided to try bungee jumping for the first time.
Despite the risks, the team was determined to continue venturing farther into the wilderness.
She barely passed the exam with a score of 60%.
The hikers barely made it to the summit before the storm hit.
I could barely hear what he was saying over the loud music.
After running a marathon, she could barely walk due to exhaustion.
The old car barely made it up the steep hill.

etched in my mind.definition: Remembered clearly and vividly; deeply ingrained in one's memory.
example_sentences: The image of her smiling face was etched in my mind long after she had left.
The ominous warning about the dangerous trails was etched in my mind as I hiked through the forest.
The haunting melody of the song stayed etched in my mind, playing on repeat throughout the day.
The taste of that delicious meal was so good that it was etched in my mind for weeks.
The memory of their heartfelt goodbye was etched in my mind, making me miss them even more.

milestone.definition: A milestone is a significant event or stage in the development or progress of something.
example_sentences: Graduating from college was a major milestone in Sarah's life.
The company celebrated reaching the milestone of one million customers.
Learning to ride a bike is a common milestone for young children.
Successfully completing the project ahead of schedule was a significant milestone for the team.
Buying their first home together marked a special milestone in their relationship.

overwhelmed.definition: defeated completely; too much work or emotion to handle
example_sentences: She felt overwhelmed by all the responsibilities piling up at work.
After the unexpected news, he was overwhelmed with emotion.
The sheer number of people at the event overwhelmed her senses.
Facing multiple deadlines, she became overwhelmed with anxiety.
The scale of the disaster left the rescue team feeling overwhelmed.

put on.definition: to dress oneself in specified clothing; to apply or make use of
example_sentences: I need to put on my coat before going outside.
She decided to put on some makeup for the party.
He always puts on his favorite music while he works.
They will put on a play at the school next week.
Don't forget to put on sunscreen before going to the beach.

psyched.definition: excited, enthusiastic, or pumped up about something
example_sentences: I'm psyched about the concert this weekend!
She was psyched to start her new job.
Are you psyched for the big game tomorrow?
We're all psyched for the upcoming vacation.
He got psyched when he found out he won the contest.
